natural problem: What is the domain of the function $$w(x) = \sqrt{x-2} + \sqrt[3]{x-3}~?$$ Express your answer in interval notation.
natural solution: Note that $\sqrt[3]{x-3}$ is defined for all $x$. The only restriction is due to the $\sqrt{x-2}$ term, which is defined only if $x-2$ is nonnegative.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes w :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. w x = sqrt (x - 2) + (x - 3) powr (1/3)"
and h1 : "\<exists>x. (2 \<le> x)"
shows  "x \<in> {x. 2 \<le> x}"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the domain of the function $$w(x) = \sqrt{x-2} + \sqrt[3]{x-3}~?$$ Express your answer in interval notation. The final Answer is [2,\infty)
 ### Proof
 Note that $\sqrt[3]{x-3}$ is defined for all $x$. The only restriction is due to the $\sqrt{x-2}$ term, which is defined only if $x-2$ is nonnegative.
 Thus, the domain of $w(x)$ is $\boxed{[2,\infty)}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes w :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. w x = sqrt (x - 2) + (x - 3) powr (1/3)"
and h1 : "\<exists>x. (2 \<le> x)"
shows  "x \<in> {x. 2 \<le> x}"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Let $w(x) = \sqrt{x - 2} + (x - 3)^{\frac{1}{3}}$. Is there a value of $x$ such that $x \geq 2$?

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x w :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. w x = sqrt (x - 2) + root 3 (x - 3)"
shows  "Domain w = {x. x \<ge> 2}"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the domain of the function $$w(x) = \sqrt{x-2} + \sqrt[3]{x-3}~?$$ Express your answer in interval notation. The final Answer is [2,\infty)
 ### Proof
 Note that $\sqrt[3]{x-3}$ is defined for all $x$. The only restriction is due to the $\sqrt{x-2}$ term, which is defined only if $x-2$ is nonnegative.
 Thus, the domain of $w(x)$ is $\boxed{[2,\infty)}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x w :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. w x = sqrt (x - 2) + root 3 (x - 3)"
shows  "Domain w = {x. x \<ge> 2}"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: What is the domain of the function $w(x) = \sqrt{x - 2} + \sqrt[3]{x - 3}$? The final answer is all $x$ such that $x \geq 2$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes w :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. w x = sqrt (x - 2) + (x - 3) powr (1/3)"
and h1 : "continuous_on {x. x \<ge> 2} w"
shows  "Domain w = {x. x \<ge> 2}"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the domain of the function $$w(x) = \sqrt{x-2} + \sqrt[3]{x-3}~?$$ Express your answer in interval notation. The final Answer is [2,\infty)
 ### Proof
 Note that $\sqrt[3]{x-3}$ is defined for all $x$. The only restriction is due to the $\sqrt{x-2}$ term, which is defined only if $x-2$ is nonnegative.
 Thus, the domain of $w(x)$ is $\boxed{[2,\infty)}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes w :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. w x = sqrt (x - 2) + (x - 3) powr (1/3)"
and h1 : "continuous_on {x. x \<ge> 2} w"
shows  "Domain w = {x. x \<ge> 2}"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Consider the function $w(x) = \sqrt{x - 2} + (x - 3)^{\frac{1}{3}}$. Determine the domain of the function $w(x)$, given that the function is continuous on the set ${x | x \geq 2}$. The final answer is ${x | x \geq 2}$.
